metadata.title: Mesoporous silica-confined ultrafine ruthenium nanoparticles supported by graphene: Robust catalysts for biphasic oxidation at the oil-water interface

Fig. 1 (a) Fabrication process for Ru/rGO@mSiO2; SEM images of Ru/rGO@mSiO2-200 with (b) low and (c) high magnification; TEM images of Ru/rGO@mSiO2-200 with (d) low and (e) high magnification. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Elemental mapping images of Ru/rGO@mSiO2-200 nanosheets. (a) Typical scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) image and the corresponding elemental mapping image of (b) carbon, (c) silicon, and (d) oxygen in the selected area, indicating the homogeneous dispersion of C, Si, and O in Ru/rGO@mSiO2-200 nanosheets. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 (a) Fabrication process for Ru/rGO(etched); (b) TEM image of Ru/rGO@(etched); and (c) the corresponding Ru particle size distribution. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 (a) Fabrication process for Ru/rGO; (b) TEM image of Ru/rGO; (c) TEM image of Ru/rGO(etched) calcinated at 240 °C; and (d) the corresponding Ru particle size distribution of Ru/rGO(etched) calcinated at 240 °C. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 (a) Nitrogen adsorption and desorption curves of Ru/rGO@mSiO2-100 and (b) TG curves of Ru/rGO@mSiO2-x. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Effect of the surface structure of Ru/rGO@mSiO2-x on the wettability and the emulsion volume. (1) Ru/rGO; (2) Ru/rGO@mSiO2-50; (3) Ru/rGO@mSiO2-100; (4) Ru/rGO@mSiO2-200; (5) Ru/rGO@mSiO2-300; (6) Ru/rGO@mSiO2-400. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 (a) Volume of Pickering emulsion stabilized by Ru/rGO@mSiO2-x. Inset images are optical microscope photographs; (b) The corresponding size distribution of as-formed Pickering emulsion. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 (a) The relationship between TOF values of a series of Ru/rGO@mSiO2-x and emulsion volume; (b) Recycling test over Ru/rGO@mSiO2-100, which was conducted at ∼ 50 % conversion of benzyl alcohol. Reaction conditions: 200 μL of substrates, 20 mg of catalysts, 10 mL of deionized water, 10 mL of toluene, T = 85 °C, O2 flowing rate for 10 mL min−1. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Schematic diagram of interfacial catalytic pathways in the droplets of Pickering emulsion. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 (a) Synthesis illustration of Ru/rGO@mSiO2(out); (b) TEM image of Ru/rGO@mSiO2(out) and (c) recyclability test of the Ru/rGO@mSiO2(out), reaction time: 0.5 h. Fig. 10 Mesoporous silica-confined ultrafine ruthenium nanoparticles supported by graphene: Robust catalysts for biphasic oxidation at the oil-water interface Lifang Ge Writing – review & editing Supervision Resources a b Lin Ni Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft b Baolong Fan Supervision Funding acquisition b ⁎ Panyu Wu Resources b Wenchao Zhang Supervision Funding acquisition a a School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Nanjing University of Science and Technology, Nanjing 210094, China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Nanjing University of Science and Technology Nanjing 210094 China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Nanjing University of Science and Technology, Nanjing 210094, China b Engineering Division, Anhui Jiangnan Chemical Industry Co., Ltd., China North Industries Group Corporation Limited, Hefei, Anhui 230088, China Engineering Division, Anhui Jiangnan Chemical Industry Co., Ltd., China North Industries Group Corporation Limited Hefei Anhui 230088 China Engineering division, Anhui Jiangnan Chemical Industry Co., Ltd., China North Industries Group Corporation Limited, Hefei 230088, Anhui, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphene-supported ultrafine ruthenium nanoparticles covered by mesoporous silica (mSiO2) were synthesized as interfacially active catalysts for biphasic oxidation at the oil-water interface. These mesoporous SiO2 layers serve to confine metal nanoparticles of specific sizes, preventing their sintering even under harsh conditions, which is attributed to the confinement effects within porous materials. Furthermore, Pickering emulsion systems formulated with these amphiphilic catalysts exhibit significantly higher catalytic efficiency compared to conventional organic-aqueous biphasic systems with Ru/rGO and commercial Ru/C catalysts. The catalytic performance is directly influenced by surface wettability, and the catalytic efficiency reveals a parabolic distribution with respect to the content of mSiO2, indicative of the optimal activity over Ru/rGO@mSiO2-100 with a conversion of up to > 92 % and a selectivity to benzaldehyde of up to > 99 % under base-free conditions after 2 h. Moreover, rGO–silica hybrids demonstrate the excellent reusability for over five cycles which benefits from the protective effect of mSiO2. Graphical Abstract Keywords Graphene Pickering emulsion Benzyl alcohol Oxidation Nanoparticles Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Aqueous-organic (liquid-liquid) biphasic catalysis system is an important platform for producing fine chemicals due to the advantages of the boosted compatibility for the hydrophilic substrates as well as the water-induced and promoted system [1–4]. However, the limited reaction interface and deficient encounter of catalysts and reactants, seriously restrict the whole reaction efficiency in the immiscible biphasic system [5,6]. Recently, Pickering interfacial catalysis (PIC) has emerged as a highly effective strategy for enhancing catalytic efficiency in biphasic reactions [7–11]. Typically, PIC involves the construction of thermodynamically stable emulsion stabilized by the self-assembly of solid particles ranging from nanometers to micrometers at the interface between immiscible solvents. This innovative approach provides a green and sophisticated reaction platform that enhances the activity of solid catalysts in biphasic catalysis, while also substituting organic solvents with environmentally friendly water as solvents [1,9,10,12]. Moreover, the solid particles utilized in PIC facilitate the loading of catalytic active sites, enabling them to catalyse reactions at the liquid-liquid interface. With numerous droplets of emulsion, this method significantly increases the interfacial area, thereby accelerating critical reactions [13–16]. Graphene oxide (GO) exhibits a distinct water-oil amphiphilicity owing to its abundant hydrophilic oxygen-containing functional groups and extensive hydrophobic carbon-based surface. It has been used as solid surfactants to stabilize the water-oil biphasic interface, facilitating the formation of Pickering emulsion [17–19]. However, as carriers to support metal sites for preparing supported catalysts, GO undergoes the reduction to become rGO (reduced graphene oxide) alongside the reduction of the metal precursor. This process leads to the destruction of hydrophilic groups at the edges, resulting in a decline in hydrophilicity, rendering it incapable of stabilizing Pickering emulsion. Concurrently, protecting the metal catalyst in the intricate heterogeneous catalytic environment and preventing the loss and agglomeration of metal particles emerge as pressing challenges in industrial production [20–22]. In light of this, the hydrophilicity of GO-based catalysts can be restored by coating them with hydrophilic mesoporous SiO2 on the GO surface with metal catalysts encapsulated, thereby enabling the stabilization of Pickering emulsion. Moreover, the metal catalyst can be effectively shielded by the mesoporous SiO2 coating, averting its loss and agglomeration while significantly enhancing the cyclic stability of the catalyst. Nevertheless, reports on interfacially active mesoporous material-based catalysts are limited, and methods for modulating their interfacial activity have yet to be investigated. In this work, we present a simple and scalable wet-chemical method for preparing metal nanoparticles supported on graphene nanosheets and coated with mesoporous silica (mSiO2) layers. The outer layer of amorphous and chemically stable mSiO2 effectively inhibits the p-p stacking among graphene nanosheets, thus preventing their aggregation and restacking. Moreover, the abundant mesopores in the mSiO2 coating help to accommodate metal nanoparticles of ultrafine sizes. This design also helps to prevent the aggregation of metal nanoparticles under reaction conditions, which is attributed to the confinement effects within the mesoporous structure. By incorporating Ru nanoparticles into these mesoporous materials, a series of solid catalysts is obtained with finely tuned surface wettability for the biphasic interfacial oxidation of benzyl alcohol at the oil-water interface. The Pickering emulsion systems formulated with these catalysts demonstrate remarkably higher catalytic efficiency compared to conventional organic-aqueous biphasic systems utilizing Ru/rGO. Additionally, the catalytic performance is significantly affected by the surface wettability of the solid catalyst. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Sodium hydroxide, toluene, urea, ethyl orthosilicate (TEOS, 98 wt%), benzyl alcohol and benzaldehyde were received from Tianjin Kemiou Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Ruthenium chloride, cetyl trimethyl ammonium bromide (CTAB), and commercial Ru/C (Ruthenium on activated charcoal, 5 % Ru) were received from Aladdin Bio-Chem Technology Co. Ltd., Shanghai and used as received. Graphene oxide (GO) was prepared by modified Hummers’ method. 2.2 Preparation of catalysts 2.2.1 Synthesis of Ru/rGO@mSiO2-x Firstly, 2 mL of RuCl3 aqueous solution (2 mg/mL), 250 mg of urea and 10 mL of GO suspension (1 mg/mL) were stirred under 90 °C for 12 h. The sample was cooled down to room temperature, and 300 mg of CTAB was added with stirring at 40 °C for 20 min. Then, 100 μl of TEOS was slowly dropped into the system with stirring for 12 h. The resultants were collected by centrifuging, cleaned with ethanol and water for three times, and dried at room temperature under vacuum for 12 h. The dried products were heated at 240 °C for 2 h in H2. Finally, the products were extracted by HCl/ethanol (2 mL/50 mL) solution to remove CTAB, washed with ethanol, and dried at room temperature under vacuum for 12 h. The final sample was labelled as Ru/rGO@mSiO2-100. In this work, the thickness of the porous silica layers was tuned by varying the amount of TEOS added. The obtained material was denoted as Ru/rGO@mSiO2-x, where x (x = 100, 200, 300, and 400) represents the amount of TEOS varying from 100 μL to 200 μL, 300 μL, and 400 μL. 2.2.2 Synthesis of Ru/rGO Firstly, 2 mL of RuCl3 aqueous solution (2 mg/mL), 250 mg of urea and 10 mL of GO suspension (1 mg/mL) were stirred under 90 °C for 12 h. The resultants were collected by centrifuging, cleaned with ethanol and water for three times, and dried at room temperature under vacuum for 12 h. The dried products were reduced at 240 °C for 2 h in H2. The final sample was labelled as Ru/rGO. 2.2.3 Synthesis of Ru/rGO(etched) The Ru/rGO(etched) was synthesized by etching off the outer mSiO2 layers in as-prepared Ru/rGO@mSiO2 with 3 M NaOH for 1 h at 60 °C. This product was then collected by centrifuging and cleaned with water. This sample was labelled as Ru/rGO(etched). 2.2.4 Synthesis of Ru/rGO@mSiO2(out) The Ru/rGO@mSiO2(out) composite was prepared by loading Ru onto the outer surface of rGO@mSiO2. The rGO@mSiO2 composite was firstly prepared following the procedure of Ru/rGO@mSiO2 without adding RuCl3. Then, RuCl3 aqueous solution (2 mg/mL) was added into the rGO@mSiO2 mixture under 90 °C for 12 h. The resultants were collected by centrifuging, cleaned with ethanol and water for three times, and dried at room temperature under vacuum for 12 h. The dried products were reduced at 240 °C for 2 h in H2. The final sample was labelled as Ru/rGO@mSiO2(out). 2.3 Interfacial catalytic reactions The catalyst (20 mg) was added into aqueous phase with ultrasonic treatment, followed by the addition of toluene of equal volume to water into a 50 mL glass reactor. The formation of Pickering emulsion was facilitated by vigorous stirring for approximately 3 min. The emulsion type was identified using the dilution method [2,15]. Upon the addition of a drop of toluene to the emulsion phase, rapid incorporation of the toluene drop indicated a water-in-oil (w/o) emulsion, while if the toluene drop remained on the surface, it indicated an oil-in-water (o/w) emulsion. The reaction temperature was raised to 85 °C, and subsequently, benzyl alcohol (200 μL) was added and allowed to react for 5 h with an oxygen flowing rate of 10 mL min−1. Gas chromatography (GC) was utilized to analyse the conversion of benzyl alcohol. The demulsification of the Pickering emulsion system was achieved through centrifugation at 9000 rpm after the reaction. The recyclability of Ru/rGO@mSiO2-100 was conducted at ∼ 50 % conversion of benzyl alcohol. Typically, once the conversion attained to ∼ 50 %, the reaction was finished and the Ru/rGO@mSiO2-100 catalyst underwent the recovery via centrifugation, followed by washing with water, and reused in the subsequent reaction cycle for the same reaction time. 2.4 Catalytic performance evaluation In a typical procedure, 200 μL of emulsion was collected by syringe after the reaction, and the reaction liquor was separated via a filter (0.22 μm) into a sample vial to realize the phase separated. Then, 500 μL of toluene was added, and the reactants/products were fully shaken to extract into the toluene phase. Finally, the toluene phase was analysed by gas chromatography and the results of gas chromatography were quantitatively analysed by external standard method. The conversion of reactants was defined as: (1) Conv. = (C BA0-C BA)/C BA0 where C BA0 denoted the initial concentration of benzyl alcohol before the reaction, and C BA represented the concentration of benzyl alcohol after the reaction. The selectivity to benzaldehyde was defined as: (2) Sel. = C BZ/(C BA0 -C BA) where C BZ was the concentration of benzaldehyde in the products. The turnover frequency (TOF) value was defined as: (3) TOF = n/(n Ru × t) where n was the mole of converted reactants, and n Ru denoted the mole of Ru in catalysts (Table S1), which was determined by ICP-OES results. t represented the reaction time. The carbon balance (CB) value was defined as: (4) CB = (n BA + n P)/n BA0 where n BA was the mole of unconverted BA, n P denoted the mole of products and n BA0 represented the mole of the total BA. 2.5 Characterization TEM images of the materials were performed by FEI Tecnai F30. The water contact angle on the sample surface was tested by SL 160E with pellet method. Thermogravimetric (TG) analysis (NETZSCH STA449F3 thermal analyser) was performed in air by heating samples to 1000 °C (10 °C min−1), and the samples were dried at 100 °C overnight before the measurement. The contents of Ru were determined by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES, Optima 2000DV, PerkinElmer, Inc.). Specific surface area and pore size distribution were calculated on the basis of the nitrogen physical adsorption results (Micromeritics 3Flex). The morphology of the emulsifiers was observed by SEM (HITACHI SU8220). The emulsion droplet was monitored by ZEISS Scope.A1 instrument. The contents of reactants and products in the reaction mixture were analysed by Techcomp GC-7890 gas chromatograph fitted with flame ionization detector (FID) and an SE-54 capillary column. 3 Results and discussion Fig. 1a illustrates the fabrication process for Ru/rGO@mSiO2. Initially, metal hydroxide (MOH), serving as a precursor for metal nanoparticles, is deposited onto the negatively charged surface of graphene oxide (GO) nanosheets via deposition–precipitation method, and CTAB is used as the pore-forming agent. Then, the remaining ammonium hydroxide, a byproduct of urea decomposition, facilitates the hydrolysis of tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) to produce a mSiO2 shell directly covering the MOH-GO hybrid surface. Finally, the resulting nanosheets of MOH-GO@mSiO2 are annealed under H2 condition, contributing to the conversion of GO to reduced graphene oxide (rGO) and MOH to metal nanoparticles, thereby forming Ru/rGO@m-SiO2 composite nanostructures. The sandwiched structures with catalyst nanoparticles (NPs) encapsulated is expected to enhance the recyclability compared to the conventional supported catalyst. SEM images of Ru/rGO@mSiO2-200 indicate that across a wide field of view, all samples maintain a two-dimensional sheet structure without noticeable SiO2 agglomeration, exhibiting a thickness of approximately 25–40 nm (Fig. 1b, c). Further examination using transmission electron microscopy (TEM) demonstrates that the entire sample maintains the two-dimensional flake morphology of GO, and the surface is uniformly distributed with wormlike porous pores within silica, with a pore size of approximately 2–3 nm, while the Ru NPs are effectively confined between the layers of rGO and mSiO2 without any agglomeration (Fig. 1d, e). The elemental mapping is tested to determine the distribution of elements in the samples for further unveiling the chemical composition and structure of as-made Ru/rGO@mSiO2-200. The energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) elemental mapping shown in Fig. 2 evidences that C, Si and O elements are uniformly distributed in the Ru/rGO@mSiO2-200, indicating that the mesoporous silica is homogenously coated on the surface of graphene oxide sheets. With such a synthetic procedure, it can be expected that Ru/rGO@mSiO2-x of graphene-based nanosheets with ordered porous composite nanostructures should be achieved. To assess the distribution of Ru metal particles on the surface of rGO, the mesoporous SiO2 is eliminated with the 3 M NaOH solution in a 60 °C water bath ( Fig. 3a). Subsequently, the morphology of rGO and Ru NPs became more evident following the removal of the outer mSiO2 layer (Fig. 3b). TEM image of the acquired sample reveals that Ru particles are uniformly dispersed on the rGO surface in a range of 1.2–2.4 nm, without any noticeable agglomeration, and exhibit an ultra-small average size (d = 1.5 nm) (Fig. 3c, Table S2). The preceding findings indicate that the ultrafine Ru NPs, averaging approximately 1.5 nm in Ru/rGO@mSiO2, exhibit remarkable stability at 240 °C under an H2 atmosphere, which is due to the protective effect of the mSiO2 layers. To verify the influence of mSiO2 layers, Ru/rGO without mSiO2 is synthesized under identical preparation conditions for reference ( Fig. 4a). As depicted in the TEM image of Ru/rGO in Fig. 4b, the size distribution of Ru NPs in Ru/rGO is considerably bigger, with most nanoparticles exceeding 10 nm in size. Hence, the mSiO2 layers contribute mostly in governing the dispersion of Ru NPs during the fabrication of Ru-rGO@mSiO2, owing to the confinement effect of the porous structure. The comparative calcination experiment is also conducted on the referenced Ru/rGO(etched) without the protective mSiO2 layers. As depicted in Fig. 4c, the average sizes of the Ru NPs in Ru/rGO(etched) grow to approximately 8.9 nm following annealing at 240 °C (Fig. 4d, Table S3). This comparison highlights the effectiveness of the mSiO2 shell in Ru/rGO@mSiO2 in preventing the aggregation of ultrafine Ru NPs at the elevated temperature. The results of the nitrogen adsorption and desorption test reveal that Ru/rGO@mSiO2-100 exhibits a characteristic type IV isothermal adsorption and desorption curve, indicating primarily mesopores on the sample surface, as supported by the pore size distribution analysis ( Fig. 5a). The porous structure in the SiO2 layers provides spaces for confining metal nanoparticles with specific sizes, and they effectively suppress the further aggregation of Ru NPs, forming the ultrafine Ru nanoparticles. Additionally, the thermogravimetric analysis reveals a decrease in carbon content in Ru/rGO@mSiO2-x with increasing the addition amount of ethyl orthosilicate (Fig. 5b), suggesting the content of mSiO2 composite is adjustable by varying the addition amount of silicon source. Notably, the water contact angles of these solid catalysts decrease from 120° to 101°, 88°, 65°, 57°, and 40° with the increase of TEOS ( Fig. 6). It can be concluded that as the amount of hydrophilic SiO2 increases, the contact angle gradually decreases, indicating a conversion from hydrophobicity to hydrophilicity on the surface of the composite catalyst, and the fine tunability of catalyst wettability across a broad range through our proposed method. Meanwhile, in the water-toluene biphasic system with a volume ratio of 1:1, the stable emulsion volume of the catalyst increased proportionally. It can be observed that without SiO2 coating, Ru/rGO exhibits excessive hydrophobicity, and the inherent hydrophobicity of Ru/rGO leads to its preferential distribution in the upper oil phase, rendering it unsuitable for stabilizing Pickering emulsion (Fig. 6). However, the incorporation of hydrophilic mSiO2 enhances the hydrophilicity of Ru/rGO@mSiO2-x, allowing for emulsion stabilization even with larger droplet sizes. This trend conforms to the previous finding that particles with moderate wettability are optimal for stabilizing high-quality Pickering emulsion [23]. Further, the biphasic oxidation of benzyl alcohol is selected as a probe reaction to evaluate the catalytic efficacy of the as-fabricated catalysts in a biphasic system comprising with the immiscible water and toluene, because the corresponding aldehyde product is the key intermediate for the synthesis of fine chemicals [24–27]. Following the mixing of water, toluene, and solid catalysts, the reaction system undergoes vigorous stirring (approximately 1000 rpm for 3 min) to induce emulsification. In the case of Ru/rGO, no emulsion droplets are detected by optical microscopy, with Ru/rGO particles predominantly residing in the oil layer, revealing a conventional two-phase system for Ru/rGO (Fig. 6). On the contrary, Ru/rGO@mSiO2-x exhibits emulsion droplets ranging in size from 25 to 100 μm. Based on optical microscope analysis of the stabilized emulsion, it is evident that the average size of the emulsion droplets slightly increases with the increased amount of hydrophilic mSiO2 on the surface, and the largest average droplet size observed is approximately 60 μm for Ru/rGO@mSiO2-400 ( Fig. 7a, b, Table S4). Notably, Ru/rGO@mSiO2-100 exhibits the highest catalytic activity ( Fig. 8a), achieving a benzyl alcohol conversion rate of above 92 % after merely 2 h under base-free conditions, and a selectivity to benzaldehyde of up to > 99 % (Table S5), which benefits from the extraction effect [28]. It can be noted that the commercial Ru/C features a much lower conversion rate of 17 %, and a lower TOF value of 107 h−1 than that of as-made samples in our work after the same reaction time of 2 h, further verifying the superiority of our synthetic method and the prepared catalyst. The recyclability of Ru/rGO@mSiO2-100 is conducted at ∼ 50 % conversion of benzyl alcohol. Throughout cycles from two to five, emulsion droplets persist without changes in size and volume, and Ru/rGO@mSiO2-100 maintains consistent activity over 5 cycles (Fig. 8b). It is found that the morphology of Ru/rGO@mSiO2-100 after the reaction remained unchanged and the worm-like porous structure can be observed (Fig. S1a), indicating the structure is not destroyed under the reaction conditions. Additionally, the morphology of Ru nanoparticles becomes more distinct after etching the outer mSiO2 layers with an aqueous NaOH solution, resulting in the formation of Ru/rGO(etched). It is found that uniform Ru nanoparticles with an average size of 1.5 nm are well dispersed on the rGO nanosheets, which is comparable with the Ru particles before reaction and no agglomeration is visible at current state, further demonstrating its well catalytic stability during the reaction (Fig. S1b, c). This is attributed to the protective effect of mesoporous SiO2 on the active metal Ru, effectively preventing Ru loss and agglomeration, thereby ensuring sustained cyclic stability of the catalyst. Analysis of the relationship between the turnover frequency (TOF) value of Ru/rGO@mSiO2-x and emulsion volume reveals that the TOF value does not directly correlate with increasing emulsion volume, it exhibits a trend of initial ascent followed by a decline. These results underscore the ability to control catalytic efficiency by modulating the surface wettability of solid catalysts. Subsequently, the mass transfer process within the interfacial catalytic system in emulsion at the two-phase boundary is further analysed. The interphase mass transport of reactants in the stable Pickering emulsion is rather complex [29–31], which is briefly outlined in Fig. 9. The transportation process of the substrate is typically categorized into three main sections: firstly, the external diffusion of substrates towards the exterior surface of catalyst particles, involving both continuous and dispersed phases; secondly, the internal diffusion of substrates towards the active metal within the catalyst particles; and finally, the catalytic conversion of the substrates. It has been pointed out that interfacial reaction is several orders of magnitude faster than external diffusion and pore diffusion [30]. Therefore, the diffusion of substrates plays a crucial role in determining the interphase mass transfer and catalytic activity in PIC. The rate of mass transfer can be expressed by diffusion fluxes by Eqs. (5)–(8) in Fig. 9. Regarding the external diffusion, the rate of the mass transfer for the reactant can be quantified with the help of overall transport coefficients (D d and D c), and the diffusion fluxes for dispersed phase (F d) and continuous phase (F c) are in direct proportion of the mass transfer area (S d and S c) with the same initial concentration of benzyl alcohol. Therefore, the external diffusion of reactants is governed by overall mass transfer areas (S d and S c), and for PIC, S d and S c are primarily influenced by the volume and droplet size of emulsion. Fig. 7 illustrates a progressive increase in emulsion volume and a comparable average emulsion droplet diameter with increasing the hydrophilicity of Ru/rGO@mSiO2-x particles (x = 50–400), as depicted by optical microscope images of the W/O-typed Pickering emulsion. The observed change in catalytic efficiency relative to emulsion volume is attributed to the larger reaction interface area facilitated by larger emulsion volume, consequently enhancing catalytic efficiency. This analysis suggests a continuous improvement in catalytic efficiency with increasing hydrophilicity, while the experimental finding reveals a volcanic distribution of TOF values. Notably, the Ru/rGO@mSiO2-100 particle sample exhibits maximum catalytic activity. This observation implies that except for the external mass transfer, which is influenced by emulsion volume, the internal mass transfer also plays a significant role in catalytic performance of Ru/rGO@mSiO2-x particles. For porous catalysts, the interfacial reaction is coupled with the pore diffusion. It is evident that pore diffusion fluxes increase as the diffusion coefficients increases, with D ed and D ec being notably influenced by the porosity characteristics of catalysts. As the amount of hydrophilic mSiO2 increases, the pore diffusion fluxes reduce, thereby limiting substrate access to the Ru active sites and reducing catalytic activity. Initially, favourable external diffusion dominates from x = 50 to 100, leading to increased TOF values. However, as x exceeds 100, adverse pore diffusion takes over, resulting in a decline in TOF values. Therefore, the mass transfer efficiency of reactants is related to both external diffusion from the phase body to the surface of solid particle and internal diffusion from the particle surface to Ru. The generation of Pickering emulsion dramatically increases the reaction interface, and reduces the mass transport distance from the phase body to the solid particle surface for external diffusion, which benefits the catalytic efficiency. However, with the increase of the porous SiO2 layer, the resistance of the internal diffusion increases, resulting in a decline in the TOF value, consequently leading to the observed parabolic TOF distribution. To further verify the impact of the mesoporous SiO2 layer on catalysts, Ru particles are directly loaded onto the outer surface of rGO@mSiO2 to produce Ru/rGO@mSiO2(out) following the procedure depicted in Fig. 10a. TEM images reveal the significant agglomeration of Ru particles on the outside surface of Ru/rGO@pSiO2(out) (Fig. 10b), and these undesirable behaviours are presumably due to the migration and the subsequent coalescence of Ru NPs on the outside surface of the catalyst without silica encapsulation upon the exposure to thermal treatments. Despite the similar emulsion properties under the identical reaction condition, the TOF of Ru/rGO@mSiO2(out) notably decreased, accompanied by a significant decline in cyclic activity throughout the reaction (Fig. 10c). Also, after the reaction, the catalyst undergoes filtration and separation, and the filtered reaction liquid is analysed by ICP-OES. The content of Ru in the reaction liquid was 0.2 mg/L, indicating that without the protection of the porous SiO2 layer on the surface, Ru would be lost to a certain extent into the reaction liquid, resulting in the reduction of the cyclic stability of the catalyst, which implies the protective effect afforded by porous silica layers for inhibiting the agglomeration and loss of the Ru NPs. Furthermore, it is worth noting that the graphene nanosheets serve not only as templates with a large specific surface area for loading abundant ultrafine Ru NPs, but also as spatial barriers (similar to the mSiO2 shells) to inhibit the agglomeration of ultrafine Ru NPs under high-temperature conditions. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, a novel strategy has been proposed to easily produce the robust catalyst with ultrafine metal nanoparticles supported on graphene and enclosed by thin layers of mSiO2. The proposed catalysts display remarkable catalytic performance, exceptional stability under high-temperature reduction conditions, and outstanding reusability in biphasic reactions. The surface wettability of these catalysts is adjusted by varying the amount of hydrophilic mSiO2, and Pickering emulsion can be stabilized with such interfacially active catalysts. The emulsion system exhibits significantly improved catalytic efficiency in the oxidation of benzyl alcohol compared to the conventional organic-aqueous biphasic system employing unmodified Ru/rGO catalysts. The oxidation results in W/O emulsion reveal a parabolic distribution of TOF values as the hydrophilic mSiO2 content in the particles increases. The increased hydrophilic mSiO2 in the particles leads to an expansion of the Pickering emulsion volume, which facilitates the external diffusion. Simultaneously, the raised thickness of mSiO2 results in an elevated pore diffusion resistance, synergistically contributing to the observed volcanic TOF distribution. Among them, Ru/rGO@mSiO2-100 particles exhibit the highest catalytic activity, demonstrating the excellent reusability for over five cycles which benefits from the protective effect of mSiO2. This study highlights the pivotal importance of liquid-liquid interfaces and provides new perspectives for the design and synthesis of advanced interface-active catalysts for highly effective biphasic catalysis. coredata.dc:description: Graphene-supported ultrafine ruthenium nanoparticles covered by mesoporous silica (mSiO2) were synthesized as interfacially active catalysts for biphasic oxidation at the oil-water interface. These mesoporous SiO2 layers serve to confine metal nanoparticles of specific sizes, preventing their sintering even under harsh conditions, which is attributed to the confinement effects within porous materials. Furthermore, Pickering emulsion systems formulated with these amphiphilic catalysts exhibit significantly higher catalytic efficiency compared to conventional organic-aqueous biphasic systems with Ru/rGO and commercial Ru/C catalysts. The catalytic performance is directly influenced by surface wettability, and the catalytic efficiency reveals a parabolic distribution with respect to the content of mSiO2, indicative of the optimal activity over Ru/rGO@mSiO2-100 with a conversion of up to > 92 % and a selectivity to benzaldehyde of up to > 99 % under base-free conditions after 2 h. Moreover, rGO–silica hybrids demonstrate the excellent reusability for over five cycles which benefits from the protective effect of mSiO2.

coredata.dc:title: Mesoporous silica-confined ultrafine ruthenium nanoparticles supported by graphene: Robust catalysts for biphasic oxidation at the oil-water interface
